STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 3, 2021
Charles Rose
St Joseph County DHHS
692 East Main Street
Centreville, MI 49032
RE: License #: CP750201427
St Joseph County DHHS
692 East Main Street
Centreville, MI 49032
Dear Mr. Rose:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
8/30/2021-9/3/2021. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MSA and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP750201427
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services

Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768

Name of Facility: St Joseph County DHHS
Facility Address: 692 East Main Street
Centreville, MI 49032
Facility Telephone #: (269) 467-1200
Original Issuance Date: 07/01/1991

SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member’s performance
within a probationary period of not later than 6 months after
the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation shall be conducted each year.
1 of 6 employee files reviewed contained an annual evaluation which was not
completed timely.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) For a child under 2 years of age, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 3 months
before being placed in foster care or a new physical
examination shall be completed within 30 calendar days
after being placed in foster care.
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months
before placement or a new physical examination shall be
completed within 30 calendar days after placement.
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
1 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed contained an initial physical examination
which was not completed within the required timeframe.
R 400.12418 Development of Service Plans
(1) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home
4

1 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed contained an ISP that was not completed
within the required timeframe.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEPS requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Policy requirements
except for the following:
SRM 200 Personnel Training
Security Awareness Training is required to be taken within
six months of working in a position with CW-CHRI access
and every two years thereafter. CPAs are responsible for
ensuring all personnel with CHRI access completes SAT
timely. SAT certificates must be maintained in all employee
personnel files and/or their LMS transcripts to confirm
completion of training
1 of 6 files of employees required to complete the training reviewed did not complete
the training within the required 2 -year timeframe.
FOM 722-03 P. DOCUMENTATION - Provided to the Caregiver
12 & 722-03D P.
8
Any time an out-of-home placement is made, the following
documents must be provided to the caregiver(s) at or before the
time of placement:
 .DHS-3762, Consent to Routine, Non-Surgical Medical
Care and Emergency Medical/Surgical Treatment Card.
 DHS-3307, Placement Outline and Information Record.
(D) Provided to New Caregiver at replacement
Any time placement is made the following documents must be
provided to the new caregiver at or before the time of
placement:
 DHS-3762, Consent to Routine, Non-Surgical Medical
Care and Emergency Medical/Surgical Treatment Card.
 DHS-3307, Placement Outline and Information Record.
5

3 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain evidence that the DHS-
3762 and/or DHS-3307 were provided to the caregiver at the time of
placement/replacement.
FOM 722-03B RELATIVE PLACEMENT SAFETY SCREEN
P. 12
The MDHHS-5770 Relative Placement Safety Screen, is used
to examine basic qualifications of a prospective caregiver and to
identify immediate safety concerns in the caregiver's home. The
DHHS-5770 must be completed and approved prior to, but no
more than 30 calendar days before a child's placement. All
MDHHS-5770's must be completed in MiSACWIS.
The MDHHS-5770 must be reviewed and approved by a
supervisor prior to placing a child with an unlicensed relative.
1 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed contained a DHHS-5770 that was
completed and approved after placement in a relative’s home.
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
P. 5 & 12 & 16
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business days
prior to a planned change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case closure
date or one business day after unplanned court ordered
dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is
used to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns and
the safety plan, and any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business days of the FTM.
6

6 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed were missing either required FTM’s or
completed DHHS-1105 forms for completed FTMs.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
9/15/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 10/29/2020
9/18/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 10/4/2019
FOM 722-08C FOSTER CARE - PARENT-AGENCY TREATMENT PLAN &
P. 4 SERVICE AGREEMENT
Signatures- When completed, obtain all signatures as
appropriate, including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14
and older and in the case of placement agency foster care
cases, the local DHS office designee.
If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the parent-
agency treatment plan (PATP), foster care workers must
identify, and document additional action needed to secure the
parent’s and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the PATP.
CI-17-099 All treatment plans with a report date of August 1,
2017, or later must have signatures from all appropriate
case members within 30 days of the report date.
5 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed contained PATPs that were either
missing required signatures, or the signatures were obtained outside of the required
timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
9/15/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 10/29/2020
9/18/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 10/4/2019
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
P. 1
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
7

Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business
days of change in caseworker and/or organization.
3 of 11 total foster care case files reviewed (8 open and 3 closed) were either
missing action summaries or contained action summaries completed outside of the
required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as FOM 722-09C)
9/15/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 10/29/2020
9/18/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 10/4/2019
FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's
placement date to the following
 Foster care provider.
 Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult re-entering foster care.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
- Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
- At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
- At or prior to each placement.
- Quarterly.
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
8

Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the
necessary information under law and Michigan Department of
Health and Human Services (MDHHS) policy.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
3 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed were missing medical passports
completed/provided as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as FOM 722-09C)
9/15/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 10/29/2020
9/18/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 10/4/2019
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Clearly document contact with applicable CCI staff during youth visits.
 Ensure that PATP signatures are dated.
V. CONSULTATION
No consultation was requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
Interim licensing inspection 9/15/2020, CAP approved 10/29/2020. The agency
is in compliance with this CAP unless noted within the citations documented
in this report.
Chief Administrator Assessment
I reviewed the completed Chief Administrator Assessment in which the area of non-
compliance identified aligned with the findings of this inspection.
Interviews
9

The staff members I interviewed reported despite the challenges related to remote
work and staffing changes, they did not have any concerns to report.
VII. ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be
issued a renewal of their regular license.
September 3, 2021
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 3, 2021
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
